questions.text: A 20-Year-old primigravida with 28 weeks of gestation comes to the OPD for regular ANC. She has no comorbidities or complaints. Her first and second-trimester use was normal. On examination, P – 90/min, saturation normal, BP- 120/80mmHg, RR-14/min, afebrile, pallor ++. She had reports of previously advised lab investigations showing Hb 6g/dL, WBC, and platelets normal. Coagulation profile, RBS normal. Negative for HIV, Hep B and C, VDRL Negative. The complications likely to increase in this case are: Preeclampsia Preterm labor Intercurrent infection Heart failure Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The female presents with pallor and hemoglobin 6g/dl in the given case. It's a matter of anemia in pregnancy. WHO has defined anemia during pregnancy as a hemoglobin concentration of less than 11 gm% and a hematocrit of less than 33%. It is associated with the following complications: Statement 1. Preeclampsia may be related to hypoproteinemia and malnutrition, which leads to anemia . Statement 2. Intercurrent infection —Not only does anemia diminish disease resistance , but any pre-existing lesion, if present, will flare up . It should be noted that the condition itself impairs erythropoiesis by bone marrow depression. Statement 3. Anemia is one of the causes of hyperdynamic circulation, which causes high-output cardiac failure. Statement 4. Preterm labor is also associated with anemia.

questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida with 37 weeks of gestation presents with increased generalized weakness and difficulty breathing on exertion. A month ago, she was diagnosed with anemia and was on oral iron therapy. Her first and second trimesters are normal. On examination, P-100/min, bounding, BP-110/70mmHg, saturation normal, afebrile, RR-14/min, pallor ++, peripheries are cold. Abdominal examination shows fundus just below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged FHR-140/min. Her lab investigations showed Hb-5g/dL. The next step in management is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blood transfusion In the given case, the female presents with pallor , cold peripheries, and hemoglobin 5g/dl . This means she is anemic . WHO has defined anemia during pregnancy as a hemoglobin concentration of less than 11 gm% and a hematocrit of less than 33%. In the third trimester of pregnancy, severe anemia increases the maternal morbidity and mortality Hence it should be corrected immediately.

Highyeild:

The indication of blood transfusion in anemia during pregnancy are: To correct anemia due to blood loss and postpartum hemorrhage . Patients with severe anemia beyond 36 weeks to improve the anemic state and oxygen-carrying capacity of blood before the patient goes into labor. The primary concern is to correct anemia and make the patient fit to withstand the strain of work and blood loss following delivery. Refractory anemia: Anemia not responding to either oral or parenteral therapy despite correct typing. Associated infections

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Beyond 36 weeks , blood transfusion is preferred over parenteral iron for rapid correction. Option: C. Labor induction is not done during severe anemia as it leads to heart failure and other complications . A blood transfusion is done, and we wait for spontaneous labor . Option: D. Oral iron therapy is less effective in severe anemia in the third trimester.

Extraedge:

According to ICMR, severity of anemia is graded as: Mild degree Moderate degree Severe degree Very severe degree 10-10.9 gm% 7-10 gm% Less than 7 gm% Less than 4 gm%

questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida with a positive pregnancy test presents for ANC. She has no complaints and no comorbidities. She has advised routine laboratory investigations and a use. Her P- 80/min, afebrile, BP-120/84mmHg, RR-12/min, saturation normal, pallor ++. Her use showed single uterine pregnancy of 10 - 12 weeks gestation. Her lab investigations were normal except for Hb - 8g/dL. The patient said she had taken iron supplements one year ago for anemia, but it didn’t help. Samples for the iron profile were sent. A peripheral smear was done and is shown below. The effects seen on pregnancy due to this condition are: Prematurity Miscarriage IUGR CVA Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The female presents with pallor and hemoglobin 8g/dl in the given case . In the peripheral smear, we can see sickling of RBCs. So it’s a case of sickle cell anemia. Hb electrophoresis can be done to confirm the presentation. WHO has defined anemia during pregnancy as a hemoglobin concentration of less than 11 gm% and a hematocrit of less than 33%. Statements 1,2, and 3: Anemia in pregnancy increases the incidence of miscarriage , prematurity , IUGR, and fetal loss. Statement 2. Sickle cell crisis leads to increased incidents of cerebrovascular accidents . Maternal death is increased by up to 25 percent due to pulmonary infarction, acute chest syndrome, congestive heart failure, and embolism.

Abdominal examination shows fundus at the level of the umbilicus, vertical lie, breech presentation, FHR-140/min. Blood samples for investigation were taken, and Hb was found to be 8g/dL. Her reticulocyte count was 5 percent. All of the following could be a cause except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone marrow pathology In the given case, the female presents with pallor and hemoglobin of eight g/dl, suggesting it to be a case of anemia. WHO has defined anemia during pregnancy as a hemoglobin concentration of less than 11 gm% and a hematocrit of less than 33%. The reticulocyte level would not be increased only in the case of Bone marrow pathology . In this question, we have to reach the cause of anemia.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Majority have the bad maternal and fetal outcome The female presents with pallor and hemoglobin 8g/dl in the given case. She is frail and on treatment for Thalassemia. Most women tolerate pregnancy well, with good maternal and fetal outcomes. Oral folic acid supplementation is continued. Oral iron therapy in thalassemia minor is given only when the laboratory diagnosis of iron deficiency is established. Blood transfusion is rarely indicated .

Labor and delivery management are usual. Patients with thalassemia major are often small in stature, with a small pelvis. Cesarean delivery is usually required .

questions.text: A 37 years multipara construction laborer has a blood picture showing hypochromic anisocytosis. This is most likely indicative of:

options.label: D
options.text: Combined iron and folic acid deficiency

questions.correct_answer: D. Combined iron and folic acid deficiency
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Combined iron and folic acid deficiency Anisocytosis is a variation in the size of the red blood cells. It is seen in cases of anemia. The most common type of anemia in pregnant females in India and other tropical countries is Dimorphic anemia, which is associated with a deficiency of iron and vitamin B12 and folic acid. Bone marrow is predominantly megaloblastic (as folic acid is required to develop red cell precursors). Treatment consists of prescribing both iron and folic acid in the diet.

questions.text: A pregnant female presents with a fever. On lab investigation, her Hb decreased (7 mg%), TLC was normal, and platelet count decreased. Peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs. Which is the least probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Evans syndrome In the given clinical scenario, the female presents with fever, reduced hemoglobin, reduced platelet counts, and fragmented RBCs(schistocyte). Evans syndrome is an autoimmune disease in which an individual’s antibodies attack their red blood cells and platelets. Its overall pathology resembles a combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Autoimmune hemolysis leads to the formation of spherocytes and not schistocytes . Schistocytes are fragmented RBCs that are the result of microangiopathic hemolysis. Autoimmune destruction of RBCs leads to the formation of spherocytes. Hence, Evans syndrome is the least likely possibility in this clinical scenario.

Highyeild:

MISSISSIPPI CLASSIFICATION Class 1: Plt <50,000/mm³ AST OR ALT > 70 IU/L LDH > 600 U/L Class 2: Plt 50,000 - 100,000/mm³ AST or ALT > 70 IU/L LDH > 600 U/L Class 3: PLT 100,000-150,000/mm³ AST OR ALT > 70 IU/L LDH > 600 U/L

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. DIC presents with sudden onset fever (as the M/c cause of DIC is sepsis ) Excessive bleeding may lead to Platelet consumption may lead to Leukocyte count is not affected. Intravascular microangiopathic hemolysis can lead to schistocytes on peripheral smears. Option: B. TTP e., Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, presents with a pentad of: Fever Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia , leading to anemia and fragmentation of RBCs Thrombocytopenia Neurologic symptoms Renal failure. Option, C. HELLP syndrome, presents with the combination of: Hemolysis because of which fragmented RBCs may be seen Elevated liver enzymes and Low platelet count Fever may or may not be present.
